mention or give access to someone else i can also require only signed urls or

um there is a versioning feature within s3 as well that really gives me the

still remain in s3 i can also enable mfa delete which requires a multi-factor authentication before i

now s3 also gives you the capability to do server-side encryption at rest so really from a from your perspective if

so when you send in your content via the or the files via the s3 api in the http
header you are enabling the uh encryption uh encryption flag now
what happens next is s3 is actually managing a master key and there is a key

generates an envelope key and it's encrypting your files before those are being stored

key inside of s3 as well a point to note here is that both the encrypted key the

10.0.0.0.16 vpc and inside of that vpc i have full control over the network

really the it it gives you four different scenarios on how you can use the vpc first of all
just imagine if you have uh you know just a public application that you're running just like normal ec2
and you want to put it in vpc so i create a public subnet as you can see
with a slash 24 in it and inside the route table i really route the traffic uh via the internet gateway
which is a virtual interface into the internet into the public internet i do
get full control uh both on the ingress and egress filters um and so
i i control who can have access or send in packets to the to the public subnet
now the other scenario is where say i wanted to only have my instances or my
application talking to my corporate data center where say i have my database or some other uh tier of my
application really running so in that case again i can create a private subnet
in this case 10.0.1.0.24 and i can route it such that
the only communication to this subnet is via the vpn gateway which is
over a vpn ipsec tunnel back to my physical router that lives in
the corporate data center the third scenario is where i have both private and public subnets and i have a
route table that i have configured that determine how the traffic from each one
of the subnets or to the subnets is coming too
and then in a scenario where the force scenario where say some of my instances
do need to talk to public endpoints like s3 or other uh
internet uh you know services or endpoints or resources i can
create a nat instance which is really a network address translation um instance
that will basically pass the traffic from my private subnet
via the nad instance into the internet so really i have full control over how
the routing between these two different subnets are happening
so four different scenarios as we talked about additional ec2 security controls

on that ec2 guest os aws has no visibility on your

create a default security group which is basically you have no access to
the instance unless you explicitly say so so let's take the example of say if
i'm spinning up a streaming say adobe media server on an ec2
instance how would i create the security group for that so
adobe media server requires ports tcp port 80 tcp port 1111 tcp udp 1935 open
so basically i open it to public in that way my fms streaming server works fine
because i'm allowing that access now i do need access sort of like
ssh into the instance now that could be a bastion host or you know some other

x origin access identity so within iam you can create a cloudfront origin access identity and

origin fetches so what that means is when cloudfront is requesting the
content in the case of a cache miss from s3 that transfer from s3 into cloudfront is
over https only and that also holds for custom origin so
in the case say i have my own say origin servers in ec2 or even in my
